title: The fact that 25%-30% of games are considered traps games is concerning.

embed.description: Hey folks, Since patch 8.11 dropped, we’ve seen a pretty large shakeup to the bot lane meta which has been as polarizing as it has been refreshing.

body:
According to Maple, 25%-30% of games are considered traps games. Isn't it concerning?

Only a few of my games were actual traps but were ff at 20 anyway. Now,  indeed 30% feels more accurate but that's something you've lead us to. 

That number is so high that I find quite amusing that you're "satisfied, when according to your statistics, **30% of the current games are 90 to 100% decided by the 15 min mark.** I don't find it's moving the game toward a greater state.

Obviously, now ppl find that having a regular surrender vote at ff15 makes sense. **It's just statistical abuse to make us accept your end goals** which is turning this game into a ff15 clown fiesta game.
I wish, you would share a comparaison with past seasons, that would be interesting but you won't, because ppl will realize how much you you moved the game to a worst state. 

 Your breakpoints are hilarious. 

Even Game - losing team has a 25%-50% chance to win
Lead Game - losing team has a 10%-25% chance to win
Large Lead - losing team has a 0-10% chance to win

It does mean that at 15 min mark in 8.13 :

* 25% were decided at 90% to 100%.
* 30% were decided at 75% to 90%.
* 45% were decided at 75% to 50%. 

In regards to these statistics, how can one refuse the regular ff15 vote? No one because it makes sense in the current state. Although, these curves have to be shifted heavily if you want use to believe that the game is not snowbally. 

I remember GC saying that he wanted to implement the feeling that "you won't win and hopelessness". Don't search further, it's right there already. Does it makes me wanna play? Does it makes any one competitive wanna play? No, it pushes forward the casual mentality who doesn't care to win or not.

> [{quoted}](name=warpenguin555,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=6hhqhHkY,comment-id=0008,timestamp=2018-07-24T17:23:49.858+0000)
>
> anything higher than 10% trap game rate is too high imo

So what you are saying is that on games where one team dominates early, that there should be a 90% chance that they can't just end?
No, I'm saying that the amount of games where 1 side mauls the enemy that badly shouldn't being happening more than 10% of the time.
Why ?

League of Legends is considered a team game, but the ranked system is based on you as a solo (or duo) queue individual. The game states allows one lane to get so snowballed that the other team has to surrender at 15 due to the 5-0 Fizz or Zed roaming and murdering every other enemy champion in one shot repeatedly with no counter plays or ability to take objectives. When the majority of the games have toxic players, people not caring whether or not they win, or just plain casuals, then you have to be THE ONE to get super fed early to carry the game. That does not happen unless you are an assassin or roaming AP mid or an objective controlling jungler like Udyr. 

Your rank is more dependent on teammates not feeding kills multiple kills during laning phase than it has ever been in the past because statistically your team is going to get crushed by 15 or 20 minutes due to one player's gold advantage. There is no coming back, especially if you are a bottom laner. You can win lane with a cs advantage and still get completely crushed by a fed enemy mid laner or jungler. You should have the ability to scale with a cs lead, but I feel like that has to do with lack of peeling supports and the rune benefits for assassins.

The more I type in this passage I realize there are so many problems with the game right. The game drastically requires a massive balance update.

I was thinking of making a post exactly like this. That whole dev blog about trap games stinks. The post makes no effort to explain how comeback chance got quantified in the first place, the breakpoints are _super_ uneven, the threshold for "even games" does not correspond to the general perception (25% chance at a comeback isn't considered "even" by most people), and, at the very end of the day, it still proves everyone's suspicions. Not only are around a quarter of all games legitimately almost impossible to win by Riot's own standards, _more than half of **all** games aren't even close_. This is, again, using Riot's very generous divisions, and I'm sure the results would be even worse if the lower limit to "even games" were set at something more reasonable, like 40% or 35%. Riot has effectively proven that League is far, far too snowbally, as the literal absolute majority of all games do not offer a sufficient chance of a comeback, and a quarter of all games are the horrific stomps that have already been talked about so much. This is terrible.

What's more, in spite of presenting us with these statistics, Riot _still_ tries to pull the wool over our eyes. The post's grand conclusion about there being "a large increase" in more even games is directly contradicted by the statistics at hand, unless one is willing to call a ~2% difference since 8.01 "a large increase". The post also conveniently fails to mention how this compares to previous seasons, namely Season 5 and before. This omission, plus the heavily exaggerated conclusion, and suspicious distribution of data all point to a deliberate attempt to try to mislead the playerbase into believing something other than the facts, whereas the poor presentation of the stats, the complete lack of explanation behind the numbers, and the lack of awareness of what the numbers directly convey all suggests that whoever was in charge of pushing this piece of propaganda to us players themselves lacked an adequate grasp of statistics. That post is a poor attempt at lying to the playerbase under the guise of communication, and is not the first time Riot has deliberately tried to mislead us using badly handled statistics. This is exactly the kind of thing that makes players lose trust in Riot, and that gives us reason not to trust them in the future.

If we assume that either team has a 50% chance to win at minute 0, how do you believe that percentage should change over the length of a game? How much value should you get out of early game victories? Or how much should you lose from making mistakes? How do champions who's strength is in the early game get impacted if we don't allow you to build up advantages? 

To specifically call out the reference to me pulling the wool over your eyes, I should clarify I'm talking about the point in time from 8.09-8.14, not over the entirety of the season. Sorry that was likely misleading. In particular the "grand conclusion" was intended to point that we were able to move a large number of games classified as large leads into the even game section.

FWIW, I can agree that it's frustrating that I didn't go in depth into all of the factors that we use to determine these categories of games, but I'd also rather leave that to one of our insights dudes. We use far more than this one graph to understand game state and make decisions off of, but it's the cleanest high level view of the data that can be understood by the majority of the players. Very few people can actually understand a lot of the more in depth factors that help make up this data (you're obviously an exception), but for these sorts of posts we typically aim for approachability by a large number of players. I regret that the tactic makes you feel as though I'm trying to mislead or lie to you guys, I just wanted to at least get some semblance of statement or "our view" out there.

I think a common and growing sentiment between players is that Riot is trying to ignore the elephant in the room. This generates a lot of frustation for players, and i imagine that happing to developers and staff too. 

Correct me if i'm wrong, but i think that the guy who you responded is, just like me and the majority of players i believe, is expressing, with reason, such frustation towards Riot as a whole, not especifically towards your post and data. The continuous attempts through posts, videos and dev blogs to show that the game is "fine" and still yet to grow further, tangencing or half-answering critical topics such as snowball, Time-To-Kill, damage creep and playerbase drop doesn't help Riot solving the game's issue.

I understand that, as a employee or leader, the last thing you want is to cause panic and share negativity or pessimism towards your game to the community. But sometimes, adressing the critical issues with honesty, full-words and sincerity, even if that hurts, is the best choice.

Then again, this isn't something particular to you. Is something that has being happening over the years. It's only natural that one day or another people would reach their limit.

Can you define an earlygame victory?

Is it getting 1 kill in lane?
Is it winning 2/3 or 3/3 lanes?

I'm gonna be honest with you: I haven't played the game on a regular basis for months now. I am not satisfied with the state of the game, both strategy-wise and balance wise.

If we assume both teams start out with an equal chance at winning (50%) then small fights, skirmishes and teamfights should build up the win-chance over time.

Right now a lost fight in lane feels too impactful on the grand scheme. If I had to put it into numbers a lost fight in mid feels like the win-chance for the victors team jumped from 50% to 62.5% just thanks to 1 play.

It's even more extreme in bot, it might as well jump from 50 -> 75%.

Winning a few early fights shouldn't have such a big impact on the game.

Let's get snowballing right in here:
Snowballing shouldn't happen that rapid.Snowballing should be a slow, continuous effort. Both as a player and as a team.

You want to snowball as a player? Get that one extra minion every wave. Outplay your enemy time and time again.

And as a team? Get that dragon, get that herald, fight for your buffs, fight for every resource on the map if contested.

To make it simple: The game is too dang fast. Getting that small lead and building up on that is what an enjoyable experience is to me.

> [{quoted}](name=Maple Nectar,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=6hhqhHkY,comment-id=00110001,timestamp=2018-07-25T20:13:26.284+0000)
>
> If we assume that either team has a 50% chance to win at minute 0, how do you believe that percentage should change over the length of a game?

This may just be my opinion, but the average game should not have this percentage distribution drop below 33/66. Assuming both teams are equally matched, games should progress in such a way that there should _always_ be a meaningful chance at coming back at every stage. If there is no realistic chance for a team to win, the game should end right then and there, and should not require a surrender vote to do so. Again, this is only my opinion, but I do not consider a 25% comeback chance or below to be especially realistic, which is why it concerns me so much that over half of all games do not offer a sufficient chance at a comeback, and a quarter of all games over virtually no comeback chance at all.

> [{quoted}](name=Maple Nectar,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=6hhqhHkY,comment-id=00110001,timestamp=2018-07-25T20:13:26.284+0000)
>
> How much value should you get out of early game victories?

Why focus on the early game so much? If a champion wins the early game, they should be able to take a tower, set their opponent behind and/or roam to other lanes, all of which should give momentum, even if it should not in any way decide games then and there. If anything, early game victories should have the least defining impact relative to mid or late game victories, because early game victories influence how likely a team is to win in the mid and late game, due to how League rewards wins with raw combat power.

> [{quoted}](name=Maple Nectar,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=6hhqhHkY,comment-id=00110001,timestamp=2018-07-25T20:13:26.284+0000)
>
> Or how much should you lose from making mistakes?

League should give room to make mistakes and take risks, and should not disproportionately punish them based on whichever arbitrary period of time one has chosen in the match. I don't speak for others, but I like the Dominion score model where the same action produces the same reward at all stages, and leads towards inevitable victory. SR could take a page from this kind of pacing, since currently it seems like Riot's way of accelerating the pacing of matches there has been to have each small victory generate far too large an advantage.

> [{quoted}](name=Maple Nectar,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=6hhqhHkY,comment-id=00110001,timestamp=2018-07-25T20:13:26.284+0000)
>
> How do champions who's strength is in the early game get impacted if we don't allow you to build up advantages? 

That is for the balance team to decide for if these champions suffer. If these champions feel like they can't bully sufficiently, increase their base power. If they feel useless on their team even after they won their lane, to the point of being a detriment, then reduce how much they fall off.

> [{quoted}](name=Maple Nectar,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=6hhqhHkY,comment-id=00110001,timestamp=2018-07-25T20:13:26.284+0000)

Sorry that was likely misleading. In particular the "grand conclusion" was intended to point that we were able to move a large number of games classified as large leads into the even game section.

If you could achieve such progress over such a period of time, then why didn't you do that for the entire rest of the season? At the end of the day, you're still patting yourself on the back for returning to the status quo, one that players at large seem to find very dissatisfactory. You're basically Bart in this Simpsons clip:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=q8AULZ2le28

No matter which side of that ambiguous phrasing you choose, the fact remains that your post tried to convince us players that there was some sort of progress at hand and that comebacks in games were improving, neither of which is true in a larger context. You took no time to mention that the number of games with a below-25% comeback chance was something to improve upon, and in fact you did not even announce plans to continue improving on this. That post was all self-satisfaction and self-congratulation for a job well done: at best, this does not demonstrate particularly good awareness of how players as a collective have been feeling about the state of comebacks, and at worst it is a deliberate attempt at deceiving players into believing things are fine, in spite of data that shows otherwise. Again, this is not the first time this has happened, and we've seen similar propaganda pieces to defend Dynamic Queue and the state of top lane.

> [{quoted}](name=Maple Nectar,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=6hhqhHkY,comment-id=00110001,timestamp=2018-07-25T20:13:26.284+0000)

No insight was given onto how Riot went about calculating comeback chance in games, or what a "comeback chance" represents (how do you define a comeback? When in a match does a comeback happen? Those statistics you produced could have been based on counting chickens in Missouri, and we'd be none the wiser.

Explaining yourself just a little more, as Riot had once done in the past to explain their design terminology, would not have harmed the approachability of your post. I don't know about you, but I'd also rather have a post that is slightly less approachable, but that at least makes sense, rather than one that looks nice to a wider audience while lacking in real substance. Stuff like the range you selected for categorization, the time period for your graph, and the very numbers shown on said graph are all objective facts, and they all point towards your post being dishonest in its presentation. This is the same kind of deceit under the guise of statistics as that dev post that used Vietnam to discuss the state of top lane in NA. What you are telling me about "your view" is that Riot apparently took a look at this graph, or whichever data behind it, saw that the absolute majority of their games had less than a one-in-four chance of producing a comeback, and is okay with this, as the company apparently once was with Dynamic Queue in similar posts. If that is indeed the case, then you're not only trying to fool us players, you're trying to fool yourself.

You want to fix the snowball issue? Remove the runes... COMPLETELY, then nerf first tower gold a bit, and boom done, SNOWBALL GONE. 

Obviously this will require a huge amount of re-balancing champs, but you HAVE to rip that band-aid off.

It's a little high, but....

a) there's still a chance to win in those games, by Riot's own admission

b) those games *have* to exist in a world where solo carrying (or anything approximating that) is possible. This is the same thing that people complain about on the other side, when stomping your lane doesn't matter. Stomping your lane should matter, and when it does, trapped games are going to happen. 

Don't be deceived by the name; trapped games don't happen from minute 1. They happen because one team gets outplayed, time and time again, early on. This is same thing that people have been complaining about for *years*. When you can't win early in this game, marksmen are mandatory because late game is mandatory. You have to have a balance between trapped games and totally even games; Riot agrees with you it has been bad, but let's not swing the pendulum too far in the other direction, please!

In these scenarios you are stuck in a game for 20 minutes (at the minimum) - sometimes because a troll refuses to give up, sometimes because half your team genuinely thinks that the statistics don't matter and the other team will make the infinitesimally small mistake that will break the game the other direction... quite possibly because that was the state of the game a year ago.  

If Riot created a more balanced approach to games that fall into that category to be forfeited at an earlier time, I think it would alleviate some of the pressure regarding this conversation.

I think that is part of the consideration. They are considering testing an earlier surrender option in some regions. I will be one of the people lamenting the shorter game length overall (and have been), but I'm not convinced that it hasn't resulted in a healthier experience overall.

Hi.

Trapped games are defined by the chances of comeback. So it does no only display outplays but the ease at which an early lead can be turned to victory. The number of them displays the ease to obtain such a lead. 

0 to 10% of chances to comeback in 25% of the games at 15 min in the game is not a litte high, it's astronomical.

Winning the lane should matter but not to a point where it decides the fate of the game for the 9 other ppl at 15 min in the game.
